case_name: Sumitra Devi and Kamala Devi v. Bachulal and Ors.

facts.text: Ram Kishori Lal Sao died in September 1927.

anchor.surface_text: who died in September 1927. One of the plaintiffs, Kalicharan, died during the pendency of the suit and his heirs were brought on the record as plaintiffs in his stead. The defendants were Sumitra Devi, widow of the late Ram Kishori Lal,  defendant No. 1  and Kamala Devi, daughter of the late Ram Kishori Lal  defendant -No. 2 .

facts.text: Sumitra Devi brought a suit for partition of properties left by Ram Kishori Lal, registered as Title Suit No. 664 of 1927 in the Court of the Subordinate Judge of Asansol.

anchor.surface_text: Shortly after his death Sumitra Devi, for herself and as guardian of her two children, Lachmi Narain and Kamala, brought a suit against her step. sons for partition of the properties left by her husband. This suit was registered as Title Suit No. 664 of 1927 in the Court of the Subordinate Judge of Asansol.

facts.text: Preliminary decree passed in partition suit on July 22, 1933.

anchor.surface_text: A preliminary decree was passed in the suit on July 22, 1933, and a final decree on June 29, 1936. This decree provided for payment of Rs. 10,000 as expenses for the marriage of the minor daughter Kamala, in addition to a maintenance allowance of Rs. 50 per month to her until she was married.

facts.text: Final decree in partition suit passed on June 29, 1936.

anchor.surface_text: A preliminary decree was passed in the suit on July 22, 1933, and a final decree on June 29, 1936. This decree provided for payment of Rs. 10,000 as expenses for the marriage of the minor daughter Kamala, in addition to a maintenance allowance of Rs. 50 per month to her until she was married.

facts.text: Sumitra Devi allotted one-third share of the estate, including four houses on Municipal Holding Nos. 116, 17, 26 and 27 of Circle 4 of the Asansol Municipality, value about Rs. 19,000.

anchor.surface_text: By reason of the death of Lachmi Narain before the final decree, Sumitra Devi got one-third share of the estate, one- sixth in her capacity as widow and one-sixth as the mother of her pre-deceased son. The allotment in favour of Sumitra Devi companysisted mostly of house properties, and the four houses of her share with which we are companycerned in this litigation were described in a schedule to the plaint and stood on Municipal Holding Nos. 116, 17, 26 and 27 of Circle 4 of the Asansol Municipality. The value of these four houses was found by the Commissioner at the time of partition to be in the neighbourhood of Rs. 19,000 only.

facts.text: Marriage of Kamala Devi settled at Deoghar on Shivratri day in 1938.

anchor.surface_text: The case of the appellants was that the marriage was settled at Deoghar on Shivratri day in 1938 and the plaintiffs, respondents before us, had numberconcern with the negotiation it was alleged that the terms of the marriage settlement included a promise by Sumitra Devi of a gift of four houses at Asansol, worth about Rs. 20,000 as marriage dowry for Kamala.

facts.text: Marriage of Kamala Devi performed on May 10, 1938.

anchor.surface_text: The further case of the appellants was that at the time of the marriage itself, which was performed on May 10, 1938, Sumitra Devi made a sankalpa of the gift of four houses at Asansol, which was accepted by Nand Lal Sao on behalf of Kamala, and the gift was later companyfirmed on the occasion of the Dwiragaman  Gowna  ceremony which took place in December, 1938,

facts.text: Dwiragaman (Gowna) ceremony took place in December 1938.

anchor.surface_text: which was accepted by Nand Lal Sao on behalf of Kamala, and the gift was later companyfirmed on the occasion of the Dwiragaman  Gowna  ceremony which took place in December, 1938, and possession of the houses was also given to her soon after the marriage, however, Sumitra Devi feel ill and the deed of gift was actually executed and registered on March 10, 1940,

facts.text: Deed of gift dated March 10, 1940 executed by Sumitra Devi in favour of Kamala Devi for four houses.

anchor.surface_text: however, Sumitra Devi feel ill and the deed of gift was actually executed and registered on March 10, 1940, some two years after the marriage. This was the deed of gift which was impugned by the plaintiffs-respondents.

facts.text: Title Suit No. 2 of 1942 instituted by four sons of Ram Kishori Lal for declaration that gift deed void beyond lifetime of Sumitra Devi.

anchor.surface_text: the said High Court affirmed the judgment and decree of the Subordinate Judge of Asansol dated June 30, 1943, in Title Suit No. 2 of 1942. The suit was instituted by the four sons of one Ram Kishori Lal Sao, a resident of Asansol in Bengal, who died in September 1927.

facts.text: Subordinate Judge of Asansol decreed suit on June 30, 1943.

anchor.surface_text: dated June 30, 1943, of the Court of the Subordinate Judge, Asansol, in Title Suit No. 2 of 1942. Ramanugrah Prasad and Mohan Beharilal, for the appellants. J. Umrigar and S. P. Varma, for respondents Nos. I and 2. 1957. January 29.

facts.text: Calcutta High Court affirmed decree on April 6, 1950.

anchor.surface_text: Appeal by special leave from the judgment and decree dated April 6, 1950, of the Calcutta High Court in appeal from original decree No. 166 of 1944 arising out of the decree dated June 30, 1943, of the Court of the Subordinate Judge, Asansol, in Title Suit No. 2 of 1942.

facts.text: Supreme Court appeal by special leave, Civil Appeal No. 158 of 1953.

anchor.surface_text: CIVIL APPELLATE JURISDICTION Civil Appeal No. 158 of 1953. Appeal by special leave from the judgment and decree dated April 6, 1950, of the Calcutta High Court in appeal from original decree No. 166 of 1944 arising out of the decree dated June 30, 1943, of the Court of the Subordinate Judge, Asansol, in Title Suit No. 2 of 1942.

facts.text: Supreme Court judgment delivered on January 29, 1957 by K. DAS J., allowing the appeal.

anchor.surface_text: 1957. January 29. The Judgment of the Court was delivered by K. DAS J.-This is an appeal by special leave from the judgment and decree of the High Court of Calcutta, dated April 6, 1950, by which the said High Court affirmed the judgment and decree of the Subordinate Judge of Asansol dated June 30, 1943, in Title Suit No. 2 of 1942.

facts.text: High Court found ante-nuptial promise of gift of four houses worth Rs. 20,000 at Deoghar settlement.

anchor.surface_text: the learned Judges of the High Court formulated five questions of fact, four of which are important for our purpose, and on a fresh companysideration of the evidence on the record, came to the following findings thereon  1  a final settlement of the terms of marriage was made at Deoghar and the terms which were settled between the parties were  a  that Sumitra Devi would arrange for the gift of ornaments worth about Rs. 5,000,  b  a sum of Rs. 800 would be paid for meeting the expenses of travelling of the bridegrooms party from Patna to Asansol,  e  a sum of Rs. 51 would be paid for the Tilak ceremony and  d  a gift of four houses at Asansol, worth about Rs. 20,000, would be made in favour of Kamala Devi,

facts.text: High Court found no reliable evidence of sankalpa at marriage or confirmation at Gowna.

anchor.surface_text: 3  there was numberreliable evidence that Sumitra Devi had made a sankalpa of the gift of the houses when the bride was given in marriage and the question of companyfirming such a gift at the Gowna ceremony did number therefore arise  4  it was number proved by reliable evidence that the possession of the houses in question, was made over to Kamala Devi before the actual execution of the deed of gift.

facts.text: Supreme Court upheld High Court finding of ante-nuptial agreement but held gift valid as fulfilling moral obligation under Hindu law.

anchor.surface_text: In the case before us, it is number even necessary to go to the extent to which the decisions companyered by the last item stated above  item 6  have gone. The finding of the final Court of fact is that there was an antenuptial agreement by Sumitra Devi that she would give four houses at Asansol, of the value of Rs. 20,000, to her daughter as marriage dowry.

facts.text: Lachmi Narain died on January 1, 1936.

anchor.surface_text: Lachmi Narain, it should be numbered, died on January 1, 1936. By the final decree each of the sons obtained one-sixth share of the estate of Ram Kishori Lal.

facts.text: Kalicharan (one plaintiff) died during pendency of suit, heirs brought on record.

anchor.surface_text: One of the plaintiffs, Kalicharan, died during the pendency of the suit and his heirs were brought on the record as plaintiffs in his stead.

facts.text: Value of gifted houses about Rs. 19,000, reasonable portion of estate.

anchor.surface_text: In the present case, the value of the houses gifted was just above Rs. 18,000 which was about a fourth of the value of each share allotted  viz., above Rs. 73,000 . Even if the provision of Rs. 10,000 made in the partition decree for meeting the marriage expenses be taken into account, we cannot say that the value of the gifted houses was disproportionate or unreasonable.

facts.text: Supreme Court held Sumitra Devi competent to make the gift under Hindu law despite delay.

anchor.surface_text: For the reasons given above, we hold that the alienation made by Mst. Sumitra Devi in favour of her daughter Kamala Devi on March 10, 1940, was valid and binding on the reversioners.

issues.text: Is the defendant No. I competent to make any gift of the properties mentioned in the plaint beyond her lifetime to defendant No. 2?

anchor.surface_text: On the aforesaid pleadings of the parties, the principal issues were Issues Nos. 2 and 3 which were in these terms Is the defendant No. I competent to make any gift of the properties mentioned in the plaint beyond her lifetime to defendant No. 2 ?

issues.text: Is it void and inoperative against the plaintiffs beyond the lifetime of defendant No. I?

anchor.surface_text: Is the defendant No. I competent to make any gift of the properties mentioned in the plaint beyond her lifetime to defendant No. 2 ? Is it void and inoperative against the plaintiffs beyond the lifetime of defendant No. I ?

issues.text: Is the deed of gift executed by defendant No. I in favour of defendant No. 2 with the alleged collusive and fraudulent allegations binding on the plaintiffs on her death?

anchor.surface_text: Is it void and inoperative against the plaintiffs beyond the lifetime of defendant No. I ? Is the deed of gift executed by defendant No. I in favour of defendant No. 2 with the alleged collusive and fraudulent allegations binding on the plaintiffs on her death ?

issues.text: Whether Sumitra Devi had an absolute right of disposal in the share allotted to her on partition under Mitakshara law?

anchor.surface_text: It may be convenient to dispose of, first, the argument somewhat faintly advanced on behalf of the appellants that even prior to the enactment of the Hindu Succession Act, 1956, Sumitra Devi had an absolute right of disposal in the share allotted to her on partition in 1933-36 under Mitakshara law.

issues.text: Whether Sumitra Devi was competent to make a gift of a reasonable portion of the estate of her husband to her daughter Kamala Devi as a marriage dowry in pursuance and fulfilment of an ante-nuptial agreement, even though the gift was made some two years after the marriage ceremony?

anchor.surface_text: This brings us to a consideration of the principal point argued before us on behalf of the appellants, namely, whether Sumitra Devi was competent to make a gift of a reasonable portion of the estate of her husband to her daughter Kamala, Devi as a marriage dowry in pursuance and fulfilment of an ante-nuptial agreement, even though the gift was made some two years after the marriage ceremony.

issues.text: Whether section 123 of the Transfer of Property Act prevents the validity of the gift under Hindu law as made on the occasion of marriage despite later execution?
Whether in view of section 14 of the Hindu Succession Act, 1956, the plaintiffs-respondents were not entitled to the reliefs which they claimed?

arguments.claim: Interest of Sumitra is maintenance grant, no alienation right; even if widow-like, only reasonable at time of marriage/Gowna; TPA s.123 requires contemporaneous registration.

anchor.surface_text: Basing his decision on the aforesaid findings of fact, the learned Subordinate Judge held that the interest created in favour of Sumitra Devi in respect of the properties allotted to her on partition was in the nature of an ordinary maintenance grant and she had numberright to alienate the same in favour of her daughter. Even if she had the limited right of disposal, as in the case of a Hindu widow, she was number companypetent to execute any deed of gift, except with regard to a reasonable portion of the estate of her husband at the time of the marriage of Kamala Devi or on the occasion of the Gowna ceremony. Though the learned Subordinate Judge found that the properties given to Kamala Devi companystituted a reasonable portion of the estate, he held that the gift number having been made at the time of the marriage or on the occasion of the Gowna ceremony in accordance with the provi- sions of s. 123, Transfer of Property Act, was number binding on the plaintiffs-respondents and companyld number operate beyond the lifetime of Sumitra Devi.

Mahadeo Prasad Singh  1 , the learned Judges of the High Court pointed out that even in cases governed by the Mitakshara  the parties in this case are admittedly governed by the Benares school of Mitakshara law  the share allotted to Sumitra Devi on partition was number her stridhan but stood on the same footing as property inherited by her from her husband

arguments.claim: Gift too late (2 years after marriage/Gowna); not on occasion of marriage; TPA s.123 makes it only effective at execution time.

anchor.surface_text: and that on her death the property would pass number to her stridhan heirs but to the sons or grandsons. The learned Judges then referred to the decision in Churaman Sahu v. Go pi Sahu 2  and observed that though it was companypetent for a Hindu widow, governed by the Mitakshara, to make a valid gift of a reasonable portion of the immoveable property of her husband to her daughter subsequent to the marriage ceremony, the gift in Churaman Sahus case was made at the time of the Dwiragaman  Gowna  ceremony which was really a part of the marriage ceremony, while the -gift in the present case was made some two years after the marriage. They then said In the case number before us the marriage and the Gowna ceremony took place in 1938 and the document was executed in March 1940, the lapse of time between the two is too great to describe the gift to have been made on the occasion of either the marriage or the Gowna ceremony. No authority had been placed before us supporting a gift by a widow to a daughter except at the time or on the occasion of marriage ceremony. The ante-nuptial promise cannot be regarded as a gift having been made on the occasion of the marriage. Had it number been for the provisions companytained in the Transfer of Property Act governing the Law of Gifts it might have been possible to companysider the gift as having been made on the occasion of the marriage, the implementation of which was subsequent. In view of the strict provisions of the Transfer of Property Act we can only companysider the gift to have been made at the time when the deed was executed and registered.

Even if the provision of Rs. 10,000 made in the partition decree for meeting the marriage expenses be taken into account, we cannot say that the value of the gifted houses was disproportionate or unreasonable.

anchor.surface_text: This brings us to a companysideration of the principal point argued before us on behalf of the appellants, namely, whether Sumitra Devi was companypetent to make a gift of a reasonable portion of the estate of her husband to her daughter Kamala, Devi as a marriage dowry in pursuance and fulfilment of an ante-nuptial agreement, even though the gift was made some two years after the marriage ceremony.

arguments.claim: TPA s.123 does not affect Hindu widow's power to alienate for dowry; only governs transfer completion.

anchor.surface_text: In our opinion the learned Judges of the High Court were in error with regard to the scope and effect of s. 123 of the Transfer of Property Act. It is true that a -gift becomes legally effective only when a registered instrument is executed in the manner laid down in that section. Section 123 does number deal with number does it affect the power of a Hindu widow to make an alienation of a reasonable portion of her husbands estate in favour of the daughter as marriage dowry.

arguments.claim: Gift reasonable.

anchor.surface_text: In the present case, the value of the houses gifted was just above Rs. 18,000 which was about a fourth of the value of each share allotted  viz., above Rs. 73,000 . Even if the provision of Rs. 10,000 made in the partition decree for meeting the marriage expenses be taken into account, we cannot say that the value of the gifted houses was disproportionate or unreasonable.

arguments.claim: HSA s.14 unnecessary to decide.

anchor.surface_text: We do number think that it is necessary to decide this case on the rival companytentions presented to us with regard to a. 14 of the -Hindu Succession Act, 1956. We have already held that under Hindu law Mat. Sumitra Devi companyld make a gift in favour of her daughter as marriage. dowry, two years after the marriage, in fulfilment of the ante-nuptial promise made by her and that. such a gift is binding on the reversioners.

holdings.text: Mst. Sumitra Devi did not have an absolute right or interest in the share allotted to her on partition under Mitakshara law.

anchor.surface_text: It follows, therefore, that under the Mitakshara law and also under the partition decree, Mst. Sumitra Devi did not have an absolute right or interest in the share allotted to her on partition. Under the decision in Debi Mangal Prasad Singh v. Mahadeo Prasad Singh, the property allotted to Mst. Sumitra Devi on partition stood on the same footing as property inherited by her from her husband.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Partition decree limits to income without destroying corpus; follows Privy Council precedent in Debi Mangal Prasad Singh equating partition share to inherited property under Benares school of Mitakshara.

holdings.text: The value of the gifted houses was reasonable and not disproportionate.

anchor.surface_text: In the present case, the value of the houses gifted was just above Rs. 18,000 which was about a fourth of the value of each share allotted viz., above Rs. 73,000 . holdings.text: Sumitra Devi was competent to make the gift of a reasonable portion as marriage dowry fulfilling ante-nuptial agreement, even two years post-marriage.

anchor.surface_text: This brings us to a consideration of the principal point argued before us on behalf of the appellants, namely, whether Sumitra Devi was competent to make a gift of a reasonable portion of the estate of her husband to her daughter Kamala, Devi as a marriage dowry in pursuance and fulfilment of an ante-nuptial agreement, even though the gift was made some two years after the marriage ceremony.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Marriage is religious duty/sanskara conferring spiritual benefit on husband; ante-nuptial promise creates moral/religious obligation; follows precedents allowing post-marriage fulfillment (Churaman Sahu, Kudutamma, etc.); lists 6 principles from case law.

holdings.text: Section 123 Transfer of Property Act does not affect Hindu widow's power to alienate reasonable portion for daughter's marriage dowry; governs only mode of transfer.

anchor.surface_text: In our opinion the learned Judges of the High Court were in error with regard to the scope and effect of s. 123 of the Transfer of Property Act. It is true that a gift becomes legally effective only when a registered instrument is executed in the manner laid down in that section. Section 123 does not deal with nor does it affect the power of a Hindu widow to make an alienation of a reasonable portion of her husbands estate in favour of the daughter as marriage dowry.

holdings.reasoning_summary: TPA s.123 prescribes formalities for validity of gift (when effective), but power to alienate governed by Hindu law; harmonious construction.

holdings.text: The alienation by Sumitra Devi to Kamala Devi on March 10, 1940 was valid and binding on reversioners.

anchor.surface_text: For the reasons given above, we hold that the alienation made by Mst. Sumitra Devi in favour of her daughter Kamala Devi on March 10, 1940, was valid and binding on the reversioners.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Combines limited estate, reasonable portion, ante-nuptial fulfillment as pious purpose/spiritual benefit under Hindu law; independent of sankalpa or timing; TPA irrelevant to power.

holdings.text: High Court finding of ante-nuptial agreement correct and accepted.

anchor.surface_text: In our opinion, the finding of the High Court as to an ante-nuptial agreement for the gift of four houses at Asansol, worth about Rs. 20,000, is not vitiated by any error of fact or law. That finding must, therefore, be accepted as a correct finding, even though the learned Subordinate Judge came to a contrary conclusion with regard to it.

holdings.reasoning_summary: High Court as final fact court properly weighed evidence (Rai Saheb Jogendra Nath Roy); no compelling error warranting SC interference under Art.136.

holdings.text: No reliable evidence of sankalpa at marriage; finding of courts below accepted.

anchor.surface_text: Taking all these circumstances into consideration, we do not think that we shall be justified in going behind the finding of the Courts below that the appellants had failed to prove by satisfactory evidence that Mst. Sumitra Devi made a verbal gift of the four houses in question at the time of the marriage of her daughter Kamala Devi.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Evidence unsatisfactory (interested witnesses, discrepancies); High Court confusion unfortunate but not material; no basis to disturb under special leave.

holdings.text: Unnecessary to decide effect of s.14 Hindu Succession Act, 1956.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Gift already valid under pre-Act Hindu law; no need for alternative ground.

holdings.text: Appeal allowed; judgments and decrees of courts below set aside.

anchor.surface_text: For the reasons given above, we allow the appeal and set aside the judgment and decree of the Courts below.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Errors in law by lower courts on Hindu widow's power and TPA scope; gift valid.

anchor.surface_text: For the reasons given above, we allow the appeal and set aside the judgment and decree of the Courts below.

outcome.relief_summary: Appeal allowed; judgment and decree of the courts below set aside; deed of gift by Sumitra Devi to Kamala Devi held valid and binding on the reversioners.

anchor.surface_text: This brings us to a consideration of the principal point argued before us on behalf of the appellants, namely, whether Sumitra Devi was competent to make a gift of a reasonable portion of the estate of her husband to her daughter Kamala, Devi as a marriage dowry in pursuance and fulfilment of an ante-nuptial agreement, even though the gift was made some two years after the marriage ceremony.
For the reasons given above, we allow the appeal and set aside the judgment and decree of the Courts below.

edges.explanation: Holding that TPA s.123 does not affect widow's power supports the doctrine

anchor.surface_text: In our opinion the learned Judges of the High Court were in error with regard to the scope and effect of s. 123 of the Transfer of Property Act. It is true that a gift becomes legally effective only when a registered instrument is executed in the manner laid down in that section. Section 123 does not deal with nor does it affect the power of a Hindu widow to make an alienation of a reasonable portion of her husbands estate in favour of the daughter as marriage dowry.
For the reasons given above, we allow the appeal and set aside the judgment and decree of the Courts below.

edges.explanation: h5 validates Sumitra's alienation to Kamala Devi (defendant No. 2), addressing i1's question on competence to gift to defendant No. 2 beyond lifetime.

anchor.surface_text: For the reasons given above, we hold that the alienation made by Mst. Sumitra Devi in favour of her daughter Kamala Devi on March 10, 1940, was valid and binding on the reversioners.
For the reasons given above, we allow the appeal and set aside the judgment and decree of the Courts below.
